llm_response.description: The retinal fundus image shows multiple small red dots scattered throughout the retina, suggestive of microaneurysms. There are also several larger, darker blotches that could indicate hemorrhages. No obvious cotton wool spots or hard exudates are visible. The optic disc appears normal, and there is no evidence of neovascularization or venous beading.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, venous changes, neovascularization, cotton wool spots, or venous beading. The blood vessels appear normal, and the overall retinal background is uniform without any apparent lesions.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The blood vessels appear normal without signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no cotton wool spots or other abnormalities indicative of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. The blood vessels appear normal with no signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. There are no visible cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The overall appearance suggests a healthy retina with no evident signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. The blood vessels appear normal with no signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or cotton wool spots. The retinal background is uniform without any hard or soft exudates.

The retinal fundus image shows several microaneurysms and dot hemorrhages primarily located in the central region. There are no visible hard exudates, cotton wool spots, or signs of neovascularization. The optic disc appears normal, and the macula is not clearly affected by any significant lesions.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc with well-defined margins. The blood vessels appear normal without any signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The macula appears normal, and there are no cotton wool spots or other lesions indicative of diabetic retinopathy.

There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The background retina appears healthy with no cotton wool spots or other lesions indicative of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows the presence of multiple hard exudates, which are bright yellow-white spots, located primarily in the central and mid-peripheral regions. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The optic disc appears normal with clear margins, and the macula is not visibly affected by any lesions.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. The blood vessels appear normal with no signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or cotton wool spots. The macula is clear without any signs of exudates.

The retinal fundus image shows the presence of multiple hard exudates, particularly in the central and right regions of the retina. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The optic disc appears normal, and the macula is not clearly affected by any significant lesions.

The retinal fundus image shows the presence of multiple hard exudates, which are yellowish-white lesions, located primarily in the central and mid-peripheral regions. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The optic disc appears normal, and the blood vessels do not show any significant abnormalities.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are a few microaneurysms visible, which appear as small red dots. There are no significant hemorrhages or exudates present. The blood vessels appear normal without any signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are a couple of cotton wool spots indicating localized ischemia. Overall, the signs suggest mild non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows the presence of multiple hard exudates, which are yellowish-white lesions, distributed in a circular pattern around the macula. There are no visible signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The optic disc appears normal, and the blood vessels do not show any significant abnormalities.

The retinal fundus image shows the presence of multiple hard exudates in the macular region, which are yellowish-white in color. There are also a few scattered microaneurysms visible as small red dots. No significant hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization are observed. The optic disc appears normal with clear margins.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are visible blood vessels with no significant signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or neovascularization. There are some bright spots near the macula, which could be hard exudates, but they are not extensive. There are no cotton wool spots, venous beading, or other significant abnormalities observed.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The retinal fundus image shows the presence of multiple yellowish-white spots, likely representing hard exudates, located in the central and mid-peripheral regions. There are no obvious signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization visible in this image. The optic disc appears normal, and the blood vessels do not show significant abnormalities.

The retinal fundus image shows several signs indicative of diabetic retinopathy. There are multiple microaneurysms visible as small red dots scattered throughout the retina. There are also areas of hemorrhages, which appear as larger, darker red spots. Exudates, which are yellowish-white spots, are present, indicating lipid deposits. Cotton wool spots, which are fluffy white patches, are also visible, suggesting nerve fiber layer infarctions. The optic disc appears normal, and there is no evidence of neovascularization or venous beading.

The retinal fundus image shows the optic disc on the left with clear margins. There are several bright spots scattered across the retina, which appear to be hard exudates. No obvious microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or cotton wool spots are visible. The blood vessels appear normal without signs of venous beading or neovascularization.
